an7.16:4.1: “Mendicants, there are seven people worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, and worthy of greeting with folded palms. They are a supreme field of merit for the world.
an7.16:4.3: First, take a person who meditates observing impermanence in all conditions. They perceive impermanence and experience impermanence. Constantly, continually, and without stopping, they apply the mind and fathom with wisdom.
an7.16:4.4: They’ve realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having achieved it with their own insight due to the end of defilements.
an7.16:5.1: Next, take a person who meditates observing impermanence in all conditions. …
an7.16:5.2: Their defilements and their life come to an end at exactly the same time.
an7.16:6.1: Next, take a person who meditates observing impermanence in all conditions. …
an7.16:6.2: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished in-between one life and the next. … This is the third person …
an7.16:6.3: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished upon landing. … This is the fourth person …
an7.16:6.4: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished without extra effort. …  This is the fifth person …
an7.16:6.5: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished with extra effort. … This is the sixth person …
an7.16:6.6: With the ending of the five lower fetters they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm. … This is the seventh person …
an7.16:6.8: These seven people are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, and worthy of greeting with folded palms. They are a supreme field of merit for the world.”
